channel.title: Comments on: On Converting a VM from VMWare to VIrtualBox

item.title: By: mrpinks
item.dc:creator: mrpinks
item.description: Yes you can. My host is ubuntu 16.04, 64 bit, 16GB ram. I run multiple OS's in vmware player and virtualbox all at the same time. The only potential for problems is shared resources ie cd-rom drive etc.
item.content:encoded:
Yes you can. My host is ubuntu 16.04, 64 bit, 16GB ram.
I run multiple OS’s in vmware player and virtualbox all at the same time.
The only potential for problems is shared resources ie cd-rom drive etc.

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description: I can only suggest you try it. There is a free VM player. However virtualisation can be tricky. I know hyperv and virtualBox are incompatible.
item.content:encoded: I can only suggest you try it. There is a free VM player. However virtualisation can be tricky. I know hyperv and virtualBox are incompatible.

item.title: By: Jan
item.dc:creator: Jan
item.description: Can I run VirtualBox and VmWare next to each other on one machine? I'd like to be able to that during the period that not all of my VMs are converted. And it can be sort of a fallback if one of the converted disk files are messed up somehow.
item.content:encoded: Can I run VirtualBox and VmWare next to each other on one machine? I’d like to be able to that during the period that not all of my VMs are converted. And it can be sort of a fallback if one of the converted disk files are messed up somehow.

item.title: By: Tom Fast
item.dc:creator: Tom Fast
item.content:encoded:
This just saved me. Thanks a ton!

The last sentence was the key:
“Then add a SAS driver and attach the existing .vdmk virtual disk (or a copy of it). You‚Äôll need to install the VirtualBox support drivers if it‚Äôs a Windows VM.”

item.title: By: sahmada
item.dc:creator: sahmada
item.description:
Thanks for this tip.
But as you told, hard disk file ( vmdk ) must be in one piece. I tried to use a vmdk file while it was multi parted, and no way :(
I had to convert it to OVF and import it in VBox :|
Now , what should I do in VBox to make its HDD file available and working in VMWare workstation ?
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for this tip.

But as you told, hard disk file ( vmdk ) must be in one piece. I tried to use a vmdk file while it was multi parted, and no way üôÅ

I had to convert it to OVF and import it in VBox üòê

Now , what should I do in VBox to make its HDD file available and working in VMWare workstation ?
